Laboratory sessions will involve various activities related to acid-base equilibrium, redox reactions, chemical modeling, and analytical instrumentation methods.
Thermodynamics offers Geoscientists a powerful tool to aid in the interpretation of near surface processes.

It can be used to delineate the physicochemical conditions that led to a particular mineral assemblage; to discern whether a mineral assemblage could have resulted from equilibrium or disequilibrium (kinetic-controlled) conditions; to aid in decision-making in exploration geochemistry; and to design geochemical barriers and containment systems at waste disposal sites.
Applications include geothermal systems, acid-mine drainage, carbon sequestration, and other near surface environmental systems.

This advanced structural geology course focuses on ductile deformation structures within rocks.
It will introduce you how these structures are recorded and guide you to analyze how these structures develop and evolve in geological time.
The evolution of these structures can be revealed by geometrical analysis and kinematic analysis.

course_name: EARTH439 - Flow and Transport Through Fractured Rocks (0.50)
major_name: Geological Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Email:

Fractures are ubiquitous in geologic media and important in disciplines such as physical and contaminant hydrogeology, geotechnical engineering, civil and environmental engineering, and petroleum engineering among other areas.
Despite the importance of fractures, its characterization and predictions of groundwater flow and contaminant transport are fraught with significant difficulties.
An introduction to the physical hydrogeology of fractured rock.

Topics will include a review of the structural geology of fractured rocks, development and validity of the cubic law, groundwater flow and contaminant transport in discrete fractures and fracture networks, hydraulic testing methods and the hydrogeology of low-permeability environments.
The overall aim for this course is for students to better understand concepts/processes that affect fluid flow and solute transport processes in fractured geologic media.
This includes the proper formulation of conceptual models, its proper translation to mathematical models and to obtain some knowledge on solution techniques to obtain quantitative solutions.
Week No. 6: Analysis of single-hole hydraulic tests in fractured rocks and its implications (Feb. 12), Review (Feb. 14)

Types of contaminants; transport phenomena with a focus on advection-dispersive transport; development of governing equations; types and utility of boundary and initial conditions; and mass balance considerations.

Introduction to mass removal technologies for remediation of soil and groundwater systems.
One of the key responsibilities of the environmental engineering profession is to monitor, assess, and clean up environmental contamination in the soil, water, and air.

Engineers are tasked to develop, implement, and design technology and best management practices to mitigate contamination, interpret uncertain environmental data to determine the source(s) and or fate of environmental contaminants, and make predictions about how past and future pollution may pose a health threat to humans and ecosystems.
The objective of this course is to introduce you to theoretical and practical aspects of mass transport in natural environmental systems, and to learn how to model mass transport processes.
describe various types of contaminants and their behaviour in a variety of media

formulate and apply a mathematical mass transport model in response to an environmental problem statement (i.e., select appropriate ICs & BCs, recognize appropriate processes to include, and solve the problem using appropriate mathematical methods)
explain the physics and mathematical treatment of key transport processes and be able to distinguish and prioritize their role in the transport and remediation of contaminants
justify the use of assumptions used in contaminant transport models
interpret observation data in conjunction with model results and critically evaluate model results subject to (often significant) uncertainty
To satisfy the above outcomes, you will hone your programming skills, a necessary tool for solving the types of problems addressed in this course.

Introduces the main concepts and principles of ecology; the cycling of elements; energetics and structural organization of major ecological systems; population dynamics; impact of natural resource management practices and urban and industrial development on the environment; incorporating environmental quality considerations into development activities.
The lab sessions include field trips to study natural and disturbed ecosystems, urban and applied ecology.
View requirements for ENVS 200

Such knowledge, called ecoliteracy, will provide a critical basis for your engagement in the 21st century, the “century of the environment”—not least because so many of the environmental issues we face derive in part from a limited understanding of how we are embedded within and dependent upon ecological systems.

Field ecology necessarily harbours an ethical component both because of our natural affinity for life (or ‘biophilia’) and because questions of ecological ‘impact’ and 'quality’ are necessarily value-laden.

In summary, this course introduces the main concepts and principles of ecology; the cycling of elements; energetics and structural organization of major ecological systems; population dynamics; impact of natural resource management practices and urban and industrial development on the environment; incorporating environmental quality considerations into development activities.
The lab sessions include field trips to study natural and disturbed ecosystems, urban and applied ecology.
By the end of this course, you should be on a path to life-long learning as an ecologically-literate citizen.
Demonstrate how these principles apply to real-world situations (in context of lab activities, assignments, and labs), including human interactions with the natural world.
Articulate the elements of scientific inquiry as they apply to ecology/

These course learning outcomes will not only prepare you to be an informed citizen and member of the community of life on earth, but also provide the basis for knowledge, humility, and wisdom in your dealings with ecological problems in your daily life and eventual career.

An introduction to the fundamental processes governing climate and hydrological systems and the links between them.

This course provides students with a thorough background of the fundamental processes governing the climate and hydrological systems, and the links between them.
The course first reviews fundamental atmospheric and hydrologic processes, and traces the flow of energy and water between the Earth’s surface and the atmosphere.
Through the use of group activities students will be given the opportunity to gain experience manipulating real hydrological and meteorological data and instrumentation.

This course will serve as an introduction to near-surface hydroclimatic processes, their feedbacks and climate change, forming essential background for upper level courses in climate change, hydroclimatology and environmental sciences and studies in general.
The fundamental knowledge and skills developed in this course will provide students with the basis to appreciate and understand the natural hydrologic and climate systems.
It also provides the required foundation for advanced courses in climatology and hydrology.

The objective of this course is to provide students with the background to further their interests in weather and climate, and provide the theoretical foundations for upper level science and management courses.
To identify the key boundary layer processes that drive the hydroclimate system.
To identify and evaluate the characteristics of different land-use types and ecosystems that drive their hydroclimatic regimes.

course_name: GEOG306 - Human Dimensions of Natural Hazards (0.50)
topics: Human Dimensions of Natural Hazards - GEOG 306 Winter 2025
E. Mohammadi
E-mail:            elham.mohammadi@uwaterloo.ca

The physical nature of a wide range of geophysical and biophysical hazards will be explored, paying particular attention to the ways in which hazards become dangerous to humans, and the pathways by which humans can either increase or decrease their vulnerability in the face of natural hazards.
Natural hazards and associated disasters are, in part, a product of inappropriate human modifications or management of the natural landscape.
Throughout the course, case studies and examples drawn from countries and regions around the world will be used to clarify conceptual and methodological issues.
Appreciate the physical processes associated with various natural hazards, with a focus on geophysical, meteorological, and hydrological hazards.
Appreciate the key components of preparing for disasters.
Apply knowledge to compare hazards theory with real-world case studies.
Theme 1: Introduction
Introduction to Course, Natural Hazards, and Disasters
Defining and Measuring Disasters
Theme 3: Prevention and Mitigation of Disasters
Theme 3: Prevention and Mitigation of Disasters
Theme 3: Prevention and Mitigation of Disasters
Disasters in the Media and Risk Perception
Disasters in the Media and Risk Perception Cont'd + Hazard focus: Wildfires
Key Considerations in BBB
Livelihoods & Psychological Recovery
Comparative Analysis of Responses to Specific Disasters 20%

Description: Engage with the concept of vulnerability by crafting a compelling narrative that could be used in a media piece (e.g., news).
Select and compare two disaster response efforts for similar events across different regions.

Email:                     dtrobins@uwaterloo.ca
Email:                      lqzhao@uwaterloo.ca
Advanced quantitative analysis in a spatial context.
Today, spatial analysis is mainly based on statistical techniques and geoprocessing using geographic information systems (GIS).

The spatial character of data implies several methodological challenges in spatial data analysis especially related to the spatial dependence of the data, which often invalidates non-spatial modeling and evaluation approaches and leads to special techniques for spatial sampling and spatial regression modeling.
In addition, selected topics such as spatial data mining and spatial analysis software may be addressed, depending upon the progress of the course.
Several real-world applications of spatial analysis techniques will be discussed and provide context for course assignments.
develop a general understanding of a variety of spatial modelling techniques
interpret and critically discuss spatial models and their results

topics: Ecology and Conservation for Planning Winter 2025
This course provides students with a critical understanding of the relationship between human development and natural environments.
Students will develop an understanding of core ecological principles and how these can be taken up in plans and policies to promote nature conservation in urban and rural environments.

The course will include examples of how planners mitigate the environmental impacts of development of land, allotment of open space and parks, and conservation of sensitive areas and species in both urban and rural contexts.

Soil Ecosystem Dynamics Fall 2024
Office Hours Appointment/walk-in

This course examines the role of soil in the environment, its importance as a natural resource in agricultural and forest productivity, and the effects on soil resources as a result of different management practices.

It is divided into three sections: 1) introduction to soil composition, formation, and physical, chemical and biological characteristics of soil; 2) soil degradation and management approaches to rehabilitation; 3) soil pollution and the role of soil in maintaining environmental integrity.

RCH 211
Emphasis on concepts related to fluvial processes, river mechanics, the relationship between environmental change and river regime.
Fluvial geomorphology is the scientific study of river landforms and the processes that create them.

A working knowledge of fluvial processes has important practical environmental science, watershed management and engineering applications and is relevant to many other fields of environmental enquiry such as environmental engineering, watershed planning, source water protection, forestry, and risk management.
This course will examine a range of physical and chemical processes that create micro and macro-scale landforms over a range of spatial and temporal scales.
Implications of these processes for environmental management in the context of environmental change will be considered.
To understand basic fluvial geomorphic processes and their role in landform development and change

This course provides a comprehensive overview of the cryosphere and cryosphere-atmosphere interactions.

Topics covered include the material and thermodynamic properties of snow and ice, the role of the cryosphere in weather and climate, and the response of the cryosphere to climate change (past, present, and future).
Describe the fundamental material properties of snow and ice, including crystal structures, phase transitions, and thermodynamic behavior, and relate these properties to cryospheric processes.
Explain the role of the various elements of the cryosphere in weather and climate.
Explain the response of the various elements of the cryosphere to changing weather and climate.

Explain the impacts of climate change on the cryosphere, both in terms of observed trends and projected future changes, considering the implications for sea level rise, freshwater resources, and polar ecosystems.
Identify historical and state-of-the-art datasets, including field observations and remote sensing data, needed to document the current state of the cryosphere.
Identify field instruments for measuring cryospheric parameters, such as snow depth, ice thickness, and permafrost temperature.
Conduct basic simulations with cryosphere process models, such as snow and lake ice models.
Synthesize complex cryospheric data and model outputs to assess the broader implications for climate science, global carbon cycling, and human societies.
Communicate research findings and insights related to the cryosphere effectively through written reports and oral presentations.
Introduction to the Cryosphere
Material Properties of Snow and Ice
Analysis and interpretation of field-based measurements
Snow and Ice Thermodynamics
Analysis and interpretation of field-based measurements
Glaciers and Ice Sheets

This course focuses on ecological and biogeochemical processes that are linked to the terrestrial hydrological cycle and how these relate to the management of natural resources.

The objectives of this interdisciplinary course are to explore topics that integrate ecosystem processes with physical hydrology and examine the impacts of human activities on ecohydrological and hydrochemical processes within terrestrial systems.
Understand linkages between hydrological and biogeochemical processes in the natural environment
Understand the implications of land use change and climate change on selected ecosystems
Analyze and visualize numerical data and write laboratory reports

Mar. 4 Impacts of Climate Change on hydrology and biogeochem: case study of subarctic and temperate peatlands *Data Lab Part 2
Each lab section will attend a total of two “practical labs” – one will be held outdoors in the field and the other will be held indoors in a laboratory setting.
For the indoor lab, students will learn standard techniques for the processing of samples and the analyses of key water quality parameters.
This time of year can be cold and wet – students must have proper clothing to stay warm and dry for 1.5 hours in the field.
The meticulous construction of lab reports or field reports is a hallmark of any undergraduate education in geography and environmental sciences.
The careful analysis of hydrological and water quality data is also critical in water quality research and is a skill necessary to succeed in jobs in this field.

These labs will introduce you to the exploration and analysis of standard parameters in water quality analysis, by working with the data and constructing informative tables and graphs and describing what your data is showing you.
The exam will consist of a series of multiple choice, short answer and longer essay-style questions.

What does it mean to be a cell biologist?
One group of scientists might explore growing tissues in a laboratory to one day produce artificial skin or organs.

No matter what their question, cell biologists use a similar set of laboratory skills that allow them to peek inside the tiniest of biological units that make up the diversity of organisms we see around us.

Although fundamental techniques like microscopy have hugely advanced since the invention of the light microscope, every cell biologist needs to learn how to properly use a microscope to see cells reliably.
These can be very tricky to use properly but doing so could be the difference between a world-changing discovery and an experiment that no one can replicate.
These and other methods that are integral to working in the cell biology field will be introduced in this laboratory and it is my hope that you will leave confident in these fundamental techniques.

This unit serves as an introduction to the study of the function of the five organ systems examined in this course (nervous, muscular, cardiovascular, respiratory, and immune).
Unit 1 will introduce how the organ systems work together to maintain homeostasis within the body.
The organization of the nervous system will be explored in this unit.
The types of cells found in the central and peripheral nervous system serve as a starting point to discuss their function within the nervous system.
Initially gross structure of skeletal muscle including the structure of a muscle fibre and myofibrils will be examined.
An exploration into the muscle contraction mechanism via excitation-contraction coupling will be examined to explain how muscles work.
This unit will start with an introduction into the heart and components of the cardiovascular system, which will be followed by cardiac muscle contraction mechanism.
In this unit we will examine the structure and function of the respiratory system, incorporating gas laws and ventilation.
Pulmonary function through lung compliance and elastance as well as the control of ventilation will be examined.
This unit will start with the general function of immune system and introduction to the types of pathogens that infect the body.
The anatomy of the immune system will be discussed returning to the role of haematopoiesis.

The stoichiometry of compounds and chemical reactions.
Energy changes in chemical systems.
Electronic structure of atoms and molecules; correlation with the chemical reactivity of common elements, inorganic and organic compounds.
The second part of this course is concerned with explaining periodicity and trends in chemical reactivity in terms of the electronic structure of atoms and molecules.

Topics covered in this part of the course include the quantum theory of the hydrogen atom; electron configurations in multi-electron atoms; ionic and covalent bonding; Lewis structures, valence shell electron repulsion theory and molecular geometry; quantum mechanical bonding theories, including valence bond theory and molecular orbital theory.
Additional topics may include an introduction to electron-transfer reactions, including the assignment of oxidation states and the balancing of oxidation-reduction reactions.

describe the interactions of molecules in solids, liquids, and gases to compare physical and reactive properties.

Understand the breadth of health interventions and the difference between clinical interventions, individual behaviour change interventions, and population-level interventions.

Principles of Epidemiology Fall 2024
E-mail: moremus@uwaterloo.ca
This course will introduce students to basic principles and methods used in epidemiology.

HLTH 333 is an introductory course in the field of epidemiology, commonly defined as “the study of the distribution and determinants of health in populations, and the application of this study to health promotion and disease prevention”.
The primary course objective is to provide an understanding of the fundamental concepts, principles, and applications of epidemiology.
The course emphasizes the understanding of epidemiologic methods and the identification of risk and protective factors.
Appreciate the historical context of epidemiology
Comprehend basic terms, concepts, and methods of epidemiology
Calculate and interpret measures of disease morbidity, mortality, and risk
Understand and apply principles of causal inference
Both describe and identify the study designs most frequently used to test etiologic hypotheses
Critique methods and findings of epidemiologic studies
Evaluate population-based screening in disease prevention
Understand the role of evidence-based practice and systematic reviews in epidemiological research

This course will examine the links between ecosystems, global ecological change, and the health and well-being of human communities.

The course is divided into three parts: in the first part key environmental changes are addressed, including climate change, ecotoxicity, resource depletion, species extinction, and stresses on ocean systems as well as the social and human forces that drive these changes.
The second part of the course focuses on the implications of these ecological changes and population health.

KIN 310: View requirements for KIN 310

The current course is not focused solely upon embryology, endocrinology, neurobiology, or pathobiology, so these areas will not be addressed as fully as might occur in other classes; rather, the course will address the health-related aspects of these fields (and others) in relation to growth, development, and aging.

The objective of this course will be to provide students with the ability to embark upon a continuing investigation into the biological determinants of health promotion and disease prevention from a developmental and lifespan perspective.
Given that the field of development is expansive and multi-disciplinary, this course will serve as a broad introduction meant to build the three main foundations of any expertise:
Knowledge: The factual, theoretical, and conceptual basis of a field of inquiry.
Skills: Increasing familiarity with the critical thinking skills required to read and analyze scientific literature pertinent to a field of inquiry.
The confidence that one can bring some measure of order to a field of inquiry through the reasoned application of the scientific method.
Describe gametogenesis and the major stages of embryonic and fetal development using accurate medical terminology.
Describe health issues associated with/or factors that can disrupt the major stages of pre- and post-natal development and growth.
Explain critical periods of development and give examples of possible outcomes associated with environmental exposures.
Differentiate between primary and secondary aging in physiological systems, with a focus on the endocrine, nervous, cardiovascular, and musculoskeletal systems.
Explain the theory of developmental origins of disease and the roles of genetics, evolution, environmental factors, and epigenetics.

I am a settler who benefits from living on the stolen land of Turtle Island, the name for North America used by some Indigenous peoples based on a creation story.
I was originally a settler on the traditional territory of the Massachusett and Pawtucket nations in Boston, Massachusetts.
When I settled in Canada more than 13 years ago, I had little knowledge of Canadian history and knew nothing about residential schools.

In addition to listening and learning, all of us who have a passion to pursue careers in health must advocate for improvements to address systemic racism in the health care system and celebrate Indigenous ways of knowing in health sciences and public health.

With respect to the topic of human development in this course, Indigenous knowledge and ways of knowing provide an integrated, life-course, and holistic model for understanding the determinants of health.

Indigenous ways of thinking about wellness emphasize healing by restoring and maintaining balance of all 4 dimensions, and recognize that there are more routes to healing than can be provided by a purely biomedical model, such as relationships based on trust, respect, and humility – especially towards elders as well as truth and sharing via stories and cultural traditions.
I acknowledge that most of the knowledge in health sciences taught in this course and others has been historically based on a subset of privileged (mostly white, male) voices.

KIN 310: View requirements for KIN 310

The current course is not focused solely upon embryology, endocrinology, neurobiology, or pathobiology, so these areas will not be addressed as fully as might occur in other classes; rather, the course will address the health-related aspects of these fields (and others) in relation to growth, development, and aging.

The objective of this course will be to provide students with the ability to embark upon a continuing investigation into the biological determinants of health promotion and disease prevention from a developmental and lifespan perspective.
Given that the field of development is expansive and multi-disciplinary, this course will serve as a broad introduction meant to build the three main foundations of any expertise:
Knowledge: The factual, theoretical, and conceptual basis of a field of inquiry.
Skills: Increasing familiarity with the critical thinking skills required to read and analyze scientific literature pertinent to a field of inquiry.
The confidence that one can bring some measure of order to a field of inquiry through the reasoned application of the scientific method.
Describe gametogenesis and the major stages of embryonic and fetal development using accurate medical terminology.
Describe health issues associated with/or factors that can disrupt the major stages of pre- and post-natal development and growth.
Explain critical periods of development and give examples of possible outcomes associated with environmental exposures.
Differentiate between primary and secondary aging in physiological systems, with a focus on the endocrine, nervous, cardiovascular, and musculoskeletal systems.
Explain the theory of developmental origins of disease and the roles of genetics, evolution, environmental factors, and epigenetics.
Meiosis
Female and male gametogenesis
Gametogenesis and health
Fertilization
Pre-implantation Embryonic Development and Implantation
Fertility and infertility
Module 2: Prenatal and Early Post-Natal Growth and Development
PRENATAL GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT
Embryogenesis and development of the placenta
Birth defects and teratogenesis
Complications in pregnancy
Assessment and nature of growth
Factors influencing early growth and development
Environmental influences during early development and long-term effects
Sexual development and puberty
Brain development
Disorders in growth and puberty
General concepts
AGING OF BIOLOGICAL SYSTEMS
Normal declines in multiple systems with aging (Primary aging)
The required readings consist of a combination of review articles published in journals that can be accessed on Course Reserves, as well as links to specific sections from 2 free online textbooks:
- Anatomy and Physiology textbook by OpenStax college (multiple authors), which can be accessed for free at the following URL:  http://cnx.org/content/col11496/latest/
- Teratology Primer, 3rd Edition (Society for Birth Defects Research & Prevention), which can be accessed for free at the following URL: https://birthdefectsresearch.org/primer/index.asp
Lecture slides which cover key concepts from the readings will be provided.
iClicker in-class participation 5%
In-class group activities (eg worksheets and case studies) 5%
Alternatively, your group may be given a case study to analyze together and answer questions to apply what you have learned during the module.
The format of the tests will be 45 multiple-choice questions and you will have one hour to complete the test during the normal class time.
Library for research-based assignments
Only one short-term absence can be self-declared per academic term.
No in-person course activity is permitted during the period of a self-declared COVID absence.
Students can self-declare one Covid-19-related absence in an academic term.
Intellectual property includes items such as:
I am a settler who benefits from living on the stolen land of Turtle Island, the name for North America used by some Indigenous peoples based on a creation story.
I was originally a settler on the traditional territory of the Massachusett and Pawtucket nations in Boston, Massachusetts.
When I settled in Canada more than 13 years ago, I had little knowledge of Canadian history and knew nothing about residential schools.

In addition to listening and learning, all of us who have a passion to pursue careers in health must advocate for improvements to address systemic racism in the health care system and celebrate Indigenous ways of knowing in health sciences and public health.

With respect to the topic of human development in this course, Indigenous knowledge and ways of knowing provide an integrated, life-course, and holistic model for understanding the determinants of health.

Indigenous ways of thinking about wellness emphasize healing by restoring and maintaining balance of all 4 dimensions, and recognize that there are more routes to healing than can be provided by a purely biomedical model, such as relationships based on trust, respect, and humility – especially towards elders as well as truth and sharing via stories and cultural traditions.
I acknowledge that most of the knowledge in health sciences taught in this course and others has been historically based on a subset of privileged (mostly white, male) voices.
Supports and Resources
You may experience stressors that can impact your personal well-being and academic experience, but there are multiple supports and resources available to you on and off-campus.

REC 362: View requirements for REC 362
In the first part of the course, we will learn to understand aging as a socially constructed phenomenon.
In the final part of the course, we will critically assess the social and financial supports available to older adults in our society.
Explain why aging can be considered a socially constructed phenomenon
Explain why Canadian population is aging and what contributes to this trend
Identify and summarize some of the theories in social gerontology
Describe major sources of social inequalities that impact individuals in old age
Describe how major social institutions shape the aging process
Define and explain healthy and successful aging
Explain the role of family and social support in the lives of older adults
Identify major challenges in the end-of-life issues experienced by older adults
Enhance research, writing, and critical appraisal skills
Introduction to Course Course Outline
Sociological Perspectives and Aging Theories
Immigration and Aging
Physical and social activity in later life
Older Persons and their Family Roles

course_name: HLTH301 - Applied Health Promotion: Theory and Community Engagement (0.50)
topics: Email:  eneiterman@uwaterloo.ca

This course introduces health promotion history, theories, and change strategies that address individual-level behaviour plus sociocultural, economic, political, and environmental conditions and resources for health that impact communities and foster engagement, empowerment, and functional collaborations.
During the first part of the course, you will be introduced to the history, theories, and models of health promotion.
Summarize the key points in history of health promotion in Canada
Describe current developments in health promotion policy and practice
Identify social, economic, political, and cultural factors influencing health promotion
Describe and critically appraise various models and theories used in health promotion
11 Mar 25, 27 Health Promotion in Surveillance Society Engagement # 10   2.5%
For instance, you would need to remember the key concepts from Health Belief Model or Stages of Change theory.
I can ask you questions that test your understanding of the readings, lectures, and class discussions, and assess your level of comprehension in relation to that of your peers.
Quizzes will be “open-book”, but I expect you to do them individually and not collaborate with your peers when answering the questions.
I grew up in an education system where oral examination and open-ended questions were the norm.
Eventually, I managed to find my own “system” of doing multiple choice questions.
Each week, we will be working on a case study or another engagement activity to deepen your understanding of the learned material.
You will be working in groups and submit your work for evaluation.
I want this course to be relevant to your future careers and to your personal lives.
